var board, game = new Chess();

var makeRandomMove = function() { var possibleMoves = game.moves();

// exit if the game is over if (game.game_over() === true || game.in_draw() === true || possibleMoves.length === 0) return;

var randomIndex = Math.floor(Math.random() * possibleMoves.length); game.move(possibleMoves[randomIndex]); board.position(game.fen());

window.setTimeout(makeRandomMove, 500); };

board = ChessBoard(‘board’, ‘start’); $(“#board”).append(“<div class='loader'>Loading…</div>”)

window.setTimeout(makeRandomMove, 500);

item.title: Chess
item.description: At some point last semester I was challenged by one of my friends to write a program which could beat him in chess over the summer. This may have come after a series of loses to said friend. Now that summer is here I figure that I might as well try to do it. The caveat is that I am terrible at chess. This means that I cannot write a decent position evaulation function by hand. However I am armed with an archive of thousands of chess games and a simple understanding of machine learning techniques. I will try to post regular progress if it occurs.
